loans.name: Oyun-Erdene

texts.en: Oyun-Erdene is 32 years old and lives with her husband and two children, aged 2 and 9, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a small house, in the outer ger (nomadic housing tents) districts of the city. Her husband works as a mobile-phone repairman in Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia, while her oldest son attends primary school. She supports her family by operating a retail jewelry stall in Narantuul. When she first began her business in 2006, it was hard to find rental space at the market. She rented a stall at Narantuul from a person who already had a rental contract with Narantuul. Renting from a middleman at Narantuul exposed her to a risk of the contract being canceled at any time. However, in 2008, Oyun-Erdene had the opportunity to sign a rental contract directly with Narantuul. Last year, her family bought a small house with 8.5 million Mongolian tugriks (MNT) from their business earnings. Now her working capital is almost 2 million MNT, and she sells silver rings, necklaces and earrings. She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to buy more jewelry and support her business in this very busy shopping season of the year. Her 2011 year’s goal is to insulate and improve her new house.

loans.use: To purchase silver rings, necklaces, earrings and bracelets

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mr. Saroeun V. and his wife, Mrs. Chanthy Ok, have been married since 1988 and have four children, two sons and two daughters. Two are garment factory workers, one is a construction worker and one is in school. The family lives in a Phnom Penh suburb. 

Saroeun has been raising cows for more than ten years. His wife works in a factory. The couple has asked for a loan from Kiva twice. Saroeun is requesting another loan of $700 in order to renovate their house.

loans.use: to renovate his house

loans.name: Genie

texts.en: Genie is a married woman who lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband, Jonie R., who is 44 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are 11 to 20 years old. Genie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Genie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 13,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for future family expenses. Genie is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
A loving mother, 42-year-old Paulina is so worried about the lives of her five children who still live with her and are dependent on her. Instead of letting herself to be trapped in the middle of insecurities, in 2005, she joined a Kiva field partner in the Philippines -- ASHI -- to be able to access loans that will allow her productive self to flourish. 

Through previous loans she’s taken, she developed her fishing business. Profits she will be getting would augment her husband’s income as a fisherman, and as soon as her business grows, she will be able to support her children’s education until they finish college. By then, her role of being mother would be rewarded. 

Her relationship with ASHI and the loans she taken since she became a member helped her in running a business. Because of this, Paulina has solid records in repayment, attendance, and business (credit rating), thus making her qualified for a higher amount of loan. 

She is requesting a new loan to finance the maintenance of her fishing business. This loan will be utilized to purchase additional fish cages (fish traps) and fishing net to catch more fish to sell in her neighborhood and the nearby village.

Her long-term goals are to expand her fishing business into a fish-farm venture, to give her children brighter hopes, and to provide for other needs in order to enjoy the gifts of a life that’s full of blessing from almighty God and support from the good hearts of our Kiva supporters.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish cages (fish traps) and fishing net to catch more fish to sell

loans.name: Marilyn's Group

texts.en:
Marilyn L. is from the village of Guiwanon, Panalsalan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Marilyn is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Guava.

Marilyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, instant noddles, canned goods, coffee, milk, and toothpaste in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Marilyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Marilyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Yulita

texts.en:
Yulita is a 48-year-old tailor. When she was single, Yulita used to work at a store, earning IDR 150,000 per month. She saved part of her salary to attend a skills course. After she had enough savings, she found a course on sewing skills, which she attended for 6 months. She then started operating her business as a tailor and received orders for men's and women's clothes. After running the business for several months, Yulita thought that she needed to improve her sewing skills, so she then attended an advanced sewing course for 3 months and continued to run the business. 

Yulita is married to Arnold, 48 years old, also a tailor. They have been blessed with 3 children: Ayu, a 19-year-old university student, Anosensius, 13 years old, and Felisius, 9 years old. Yulita and her husband run their business using a simple sewing machine. Yulita realizes that the family's needs will always increase from day to day, especially regarding her children's education. Therefore, Yulita has been thinking of ways to improve her business to generate more income for her family. Yulita is requesting a loan of IDR 7,500,000 from TLM to buy another sewing machine so she and her husband can work together. She hopes that the loan will be a support in improving her business.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Sonanet

texts.en:
Mrs. Sonanet U. is 48 years old. Her husband, Mr. Vanthan MoU., is 56 years old. They live together on an island of the Mekong River, approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1982 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. 

Sonanet has been a weaver since she was eighteen years old. She sells her finished products to a retailer who then in turn sells them in the Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a construction worker. 

She is asking for a loan of $700 to purchase weaving materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 37 years old and married. She supports her family by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari (variety) store and fruit vending. She lives in Vallehermoso, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari-sari store and fruit-vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP). Elizabeth is borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she could purchase more stock to sell. This will be her ninth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Elizabeth aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Than

texts.en:
Mrs. Than C. is 58 years old. Her husband, Mr. Punlork Em, is 55 years old. They live on an island in the Mekong River, approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1979 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. One is a garment factory worker, one is a construction worker and the last is in school.  

Than has been selling silk and cotton products for almost a year. She buys from the weavers in the village and transports to sell in places around Phnom Penh. Her husband is a house constructor. 

She is asking for her first loan of $300 to purchase silk and cotton fabrics for resale.

loans.use: To purchase silk and cotton fabrics for resale

loans.name: Apolinaria's Group

texts.en:
Apolinaria S. is from the village of Caluya Sapang Dalaga in the Misamis Occidental region. She is 62 years old. 

Apolinaria is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Calaghughi.

Apolinaria is married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Apolinaria owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling hut products in the local community. Apolinaria has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Apolinaria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Apolinaria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory. Apolinaria is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Apolinaria from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en: Concepcion M. is from the village of Brgy. Quezon, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 43 years old. Concepcion is separated from her spouse and has an infant. To make a living, Concepcion runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Concepcion has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2011, Concepcion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Concepcion is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Concepcion from ASKI. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is a married woman who lives in Vallehermoso, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and a caranderia, or small eatery. Her husband Joseph G., who is 43 years old, works as a farmer, and also helps in his wife's business activities. The couple has 2 children who are 3 and 13 years old. 

Rosalina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosalina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 11000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th loan, she is borrowing PHP 13000, which she intends to use as additional capital so that she can continue to save up for her children's future education and for family needs.

Rosalina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann D. is from the village of Cabaruguis St. Dist. 4, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 41 years old. Mary Ann is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Ann runs a general store, where she sells a variety of products in the local community. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for more than 8 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month.

Mary Ann joined ASKI this year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann is requesting her first loan, for 10000 PHP, to be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 56 years old and married.  She supports her family by buying and selling bananas. She lives in Toboso, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1996 and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her banana-selling business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3000. Rosemarie is borrowing PHP 15000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 20th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rosemarie aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure her relatives' future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy additional stock

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita is a 42 year old mother of three children.  Conchita and her husband have their children to think about and to have reason for living.  They work together for the future of their family.  Conchita is thankful to ASHI for the loans they have provided since 2001.  Conchita has been able to support the maintenance of her fishing operation by purchasing fishing nets and other raw materials for her business.  She is hoping to catch more fish to sell in the future through hard work and continuous assistance of the ASHI and Kiva partnership. 

Her membership in ASHI for a long time gave her a chance to have her own business and to keep her busy.  After starting with an initial loan of 5,000 PHP, she can now avail herself of 28,000 PHP and can even reach the peak amount in the future for she has maintained her excellent performance all though her membership in ASHI.  Therefore, Conchita's wish of growing her fishing business more, with the help of her supportive husband, Felicisimo, who is her business partner, is close to happening because it has grown now, though not yet to the extent she expects. 

Conchita will be glad when her loan request is granted and she utilizes the loan wisely by purchasing additional fishing nets and other fishing materials needed of her fishing ventures. 

When she reaches the highest amount ASHI could offer her to loan, she plans to rent a space in the market where she can sell their fish.  With the opportunity she can get out of her membership in ASHI, she can help send their 3 children to school until they complete a college degree. 

The couple believes that when they pass away, at least they have maD. their business successful and their children can have a business they can own someday.  The couple’s hard work and patience are the foundation for achieving a better life.  

Conchita’s hopes to maintain a long-term sustainable fishing business.  Conchita is very happy to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for offering financial support to her business endeavor.  She prays that they should be blessed because of their good hearts for the poor people, like her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing nets and other fishing materials needed for her fishing ventures.

loans.name: Sotheary

texts.en:
Mrs. Sotheary N. (pictured) is 32 years old and lives in a village outside of Phnom Penh. She has been married since 1995 and has three children: one son and two daughters.  

Sotheary is a tailor. She is applying for a loan of $500 to purchase fabric for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase fabric for her tailoring business

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores T. is a married woman who lives in Bago, Cogon, Compostela, Cebu City.  She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: hog raising, general store and ready to wear businesses.  Her husband Moncito T., who is 53 years old, works in San Miguel Corp to earn his living. 
They have 6 children who are between the ages of 12 to 25 years old, 2 children have their own family, 2 are working and 1 is currently going to school. 

Dolores joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family.  With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Dolores has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.  Her previous loan of 20,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 5,000 PHP, improving the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing 23,000 PHP, which she intends to use as funds in her business operations so that she can continue to save up for the future to have own store in the market. Dolores T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Funds in business operations

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda R. is 54 years old, married, and supports her family by operating three business ventures: firewood, live stock and charcoal businesses. 

She lives in Camanse, Brgy. Ibo, Danao City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans fR. NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her firewood, live stock and charcoal businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 14,000. Florenda is now borrowing PHP 15,000 as additional working capital.  This will be her 5th loan fR. NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Florenda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress fR. earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida T. is a single parent who works hard in order to provide the best for her son. She is 61 years old and is from Maybato North, San Jose, Antique, Philippines. She is living with her son Samson, who is 31 years old and a fisherman. Being a single mom, sometimes she encounters difficulty in coping with their family needs and especially if there are some unexpected problems. Despite some challenges, she never gives up and instead she considers the problems as an inspiration.

She has been an active member of the branch from 1998 to the present. Being a member, she maintained her good performance because she wanted to prove that she is trustworthy. Because of her good performance, she has been able to access some incentive loans of ASHI like the House Repair Loan and the Market Day Loan.

Currently, she had already fully paid her previous loan and she is now borrowing PHP 35,000. This amount will be used to purchase a unit of a pump boat (Fishing Boat) which they will use for fishing. If this amount is granted, it will be a great help for them to sustain their basic needs.

Her greatest dream in life is to have a comfortable house and to have a small variety store in their community so that they will have another source of income with which she will have a little savings for their future needs.

loans.use: Fishing Boat

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Ludivina C. is a married woman who lives in Poblacion, Poblacion, Compostela, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: fish vending and general store businesses. Her husband Carmelito C., who is 60 years old, works as a welder and carpenter to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have seven children who are 18 to 32 years old. 

Ludivina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ludivina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 2,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 11th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to purchase fish so that she can continue to save up for future repairs for the house and for her children's school fees. 

Ludivina C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase fish

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda R. is 52 years old and widowed with five adult children. She is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal West, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. To make a living, Esmeralda owns and operates a tailoring business. Her primary source of income comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. Esmeralda has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. 

Esmeralda joined ASKI in 2011 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be her first loan from ASKI. Esmeralda plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and material

loans.name: Samelita

texts.en:
Samelita C. is a 46-year-old married who supports her family by operating a food vending and a general store business. She lives in Prk. Manghilao, Brgy. Masaba, Danao City, Cebu. 

Samelita has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food vending and general store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 11,000 PHP. 

Samelita is now borrowing 21,000 PHP to fund her business operations. This will be her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Samelita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund her business operations

loans.name: Handaa

texts.en:
Handaa B., 49, is married and lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She lives with her family in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in her son's backyard. 

She started her retail trading by selling candies at a local market in 1999. Now she rents a much bigger stall at the same market and operates her food trading business. 

She is one of the regular customers of our bank. Her family has a decent standard of living. Handaa is a very hardworking and active person. Her family members support the idea to get a loan for further development. She says, "I would like to have my own place where I could operate my business constantly." 

She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more candy at the wholesale price and to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more candies at the wholesale price

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie I. is from the town of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 30 years old. Rosemarie is married and has one school-aged child. 

To make a living, Rosemarie owns and operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4,200 PHP a month.

In 2011, Rosemarie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Rosemarie is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Rosemarie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her child. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophy L. and her husband, Mr. Sovannara Roeun, live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1986 and have four children: three sons and a daughter. One is married and lives outside the family home, two attend school and the last stays at home.  

Sophy L. is a homemaker and the main source of income is from her husband’s business. He is a taxi driver. He drives garment factory workers from his village to the factory and back. His taxi is old, breaks quite often, and is costly to repair. 

As a result, Sophy decided to ask for her second loan to purchase a new taxi for her husband to continue his business.

loans.use: To purchase new taxi for her husband

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Tuya D., 42, is widowed and lives with her three daughters in Darhan, the second biggest city in Mongolia. They have been living in Darhan for three years and she has been taking care of her daughters alone for six years. 

She started her retail trading business in 2000 and her working capital is 1,500,000 MNT. She is a caring mother and hardworking person who says, "My wish is to raise my daughters well-educated and  provide the opportunities that they could take care of their own living without any difficulties in the future. And I am trying hard to make them well-educated people." 

She is requesting a loan of 1,200,000 MNT to purchase more goods that she can sell during the busy time of Tsagaan Sar, the traditional Mongolian New Year.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita Ceriaco is one of the oldest members of ASHI-Antique South Branch. She is 64 years old and is from Maybato North, San Jose, Antique, Philippines. She is married to Manuel C., a farmer. 

She has been an active member of ASHI for almost 14 years. Being a member, she joins in the various activities of the institution, which have a big part in improving not only her living conditions but also the social aspects of her life.

Though some of her children have not attended school, she never stop dreaming for their future. She has already fully paid her previous loan and now she is proposing PHP 40,000 for her next loan. This amount will be used to purchase a fishing boat.

This fishing boat will be very useful, not only for her, but also for her son. He will operate the boat and it could provide him an income. She is hopeful that  this project will help her son to send her grandchildren to school.

If they are blessed with a big income, they will repair their house and she also wants to have savings for their future needs.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Hoshim

texts.ru: Очилдиев Хошим проживает в районе Шахритус. Ему 34 года. Он женат, имеет троих детей. Жена работает в дехканском хозяйстве "Ходжибобо". Сам Хошим занимается растениеводством. Арендует земельный участок, где выращивает овощи для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается 7 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: O. Hoshim lives in the Shahrituz region. He's thirty-four years old, married and has three children. His wife works on the "Hodjibobo" farm, while Hoshim has, for the past seven years, rented a plot of land where he grows vegetables. He's asking for a loan in order to purchase mineral fertilizers.

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Nary

texts.en:
Mrs. Nary K. (in the photo) is 26 years old and her husband, Mr. Chea Moch, is 24 years old. They live along national road number one about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2007.  

Nary is a vegetable farmer and her husband is a blacksmith. She is asking for a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her vegetable farm.

loans.use: To use for farming

loans.name: Siphal

texts.en:
Mrs. Siphal H. (pictured here) and her husband, Mr. Soka Kem, have been married since 2005 and have two sons. Both of them are still young. The family lives along national road number one about 18 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Mrs. Siphal H. is a garment factory worker and her husband is a policeman. She has had a previous Kiva loan. She now is asking for another loan of $1,000 to build a fence around of her house.

loans.use: To build a fence around of her house

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen G. is from Maybato North, San Jose, Antique, Philippines. She is married to Andres G., who is a fisherman, and they have six dependents. Carmen is a woman who has never lost her hope of getting out of poverty and, in many ways, her poverty makes her stronger. Carmen and her husband earn their living by fishing. Their income helps them provide for their basic needs and Carmen has learned how to save their small income for the future. 

Carmen has been an active member of ASHI for almost 14 years. During her time as a member, she has experienced repayment difficulties but she has never given up and has always faced her problems. For Carmen, money is important, and she has proven that she can be trusted with a bigger loan. 

As of now, Carmen is an ASHI member who has received one of the larger branch loans. She has fully repaid her previous loan and is requesting a loan of 40,000 PHP to purchase a pump boat for her fishing business. Purchasing this boat will greatly help her family increase their income and meet their basic needs. In the future, Carmen wishes that her children will finish their education and that her family will have a comfortable house and savings for the future.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Chanty

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanty P. (pictured) is 52 years old, and her husband, Mr. Sophal Prach, is 50 years old. They have been married since 1979 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home, one is in the army, one is a garment-factory worker and another one is in school. The family lives along national road number one about 18 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Mrs. Chanty P. stays at home. Their main source of income is from her husband’s salary. He is a driver for a company. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Sochenda

texts.en:
Mrs. Sochenda S. (in the photo) and her husband sell mangoes. They purchase mango contracts from fellow villagers before the harvest season and when the mangoes grow they transport them to sell in Phnom Penh market. 

The couple hopes to expand their business, so Sochenda is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase additional mangoes.

loans.use: To purchase mango under contract for resale

loans.name: Tuguldur

texts.en:
Mr. Tuguldur E. is 23 years old, lives with his wife and two daughters, aged one and two, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife looks after the babies. They do not have their own place to live and currently live in Tuguldur’s parents' house. 

Tuguldur is a computer technician. Since 2006, he has been operating a PC repair, maintenance and sales business. He rents a small workshop in “Computer land,” the second largest PC market in Ulaanbaatar city.  Once a month, he used to travel to Beijing, China, to buy necessary spare parts for PCs. But now he orders them online from wholesalers and distributors, reducing travel expenses. 

Tuguldur’s dream is for his family to have their own place to live. He understands that he can achieve this by expanding his business and increasing his profit. Tuguldur is applying for the loan to increase his working capital and to buy more spare parts for his PC repair business.

loans.use: to buy more spare parts for his PC repair business

loans.name: Vannak

texts.en:
Mr. Vannak D. and his wife Mrs. Sophea Dorn (pictured with their young child) live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 2002 and have three young children: two sons and one daughter. 

Vannak has been a wooD. house builder for more than four years. His wife stays at home and takes care of their children. In the past, she sold grocery items.

In December 2008, Vannak applied for a Kiva loan to building a permanent house. Because he moved to live in another village, he needed to move his house to the new village. 

Hence, he is asking for another loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase wood and construction materials to make the renovations.

loans.use: To purchase wood and construction materials to build a house

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy O. is 43 years old and her husband, Mr. Panh Om is also 43 years old. They live in a suburb of Phnom Penh. They have been married for almost 20 years and have 6 children - two sons and four daughters. Two are employed full-time, two attend school and the other two are still young. 

Chanthy and her husband are rice farmers. Mr. Panh Om also drives a motor taxi when he is done with farming. Chanthy is asking for her first loan of $800 to purchase cows to assist her rice farm. She will use the cows to plow her rice farmland.

loans.use: To purchase cows to plow her rice farm.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie T. is a hardworking mother and the loving wife of Antonio T.. She is 44 years old, from Fragante, Pandan, Antique, Philippines. She and her husband  have three dependents. Two are at the college level while the other is an elementary graduate. 

Like others, her family has encountered problems brought about by poverty, but fortunately, they have overcome the problems because they really help each other. 

She is thankful to ASHI because she has been able to borrow a certain amount that they used in their business of buying and selling rice.

As of now, her business is improving and they earn from it, which has been a big help for them in sustaining their basic needs. At present, they have already successfully paid their previous loan and they are proposing a new loan of PHP 20,000. This amount will be used as additional capital for her rice business.

From their income, she hopes to repair their house so that it will be comfortable for them. She wants to extend their store and to have a dryer. Aside from that, she also wishes to expand the business so that they can help the people in the community through providing them a job.

loans.use: To buy more rice to sell

loans.name: Khayriniso

texts.ru: Ашурматова Хайринисо проживает в районе Шахритус. Ей 50 лет. Она замужем, имеет 4 детей. Сыновья занимаются строительными работами. Сама Хайринисо имеет среднее образование. Более 7 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где сеет пшеницу. Она в основном сеет пшеницу для продажи. Целью кредита является закуп минеральных удобрений и топлива для трактора. Она хочет посеять и получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en: A. Khayriniso lives in the Shahrituz region. She's fifty years old, married and has four children. Her sons are construction workers. Khayriniso has a high school level of education and, for the past seven years, has grown wheat on a plot of land adjacent to her home. She's asking for a loan in order to purchase some mineral fertilizers and fuel for a tractor. She wishes to reap a bountiful harvest intended for sale.

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizers and fuel [for a tractor]

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie E. is a married woman who lives in Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  motorcycle transport and hog-fattening and duck-raising businesses. Her husband, Rusel E., who is 47 years old, works as a motorcycle transport operator to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. 

They have six children who are between 12 and 27 years old. 

Marjorie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marjorie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use to pay for a motorcycle so that she can continue to save up for the future education of the children. Marjorie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Airene

texts.en:
Airene T., 32, is married and resides in Bugarin, Pililla, which is located in the Province of Rizal. Airene has a store in her house where she sells basic necessities and all types of products that people use in their homes. 

She is requesting a loan so that she can have the funds needed to buy more food products and basic household necessities. This will allow her to attract more customers and increase her sales. Her business is very important because it enables her to provide better financial stability for her family to live in a decent manner. 

She hopes to provide her family with everything necessary to move forward against poverty. Airene’s dreams are to have an expanded business and to have a happy family. She has shown herself to be hard-working and strong-minded to make her dreams come true, and she is hoping that her business will continue to be more productive and improve her overall quality of living. 

Her long-term goals are to invest and build a better house for the family, fund the college educations of her four children and have full-fledged mini-grocery store.

She says thank you to all Kiva lenders across the world for sponsoring poor women who wants to get ahead, like her. She prays that they all will be blessed.

loans.use: To buy more food products and basic households necessities for her variety store

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty F. is a married woman who lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband, Elesio F., who is 49 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business.  

They have two children who are 11 and 26 years old. 

Betty joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Betty has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her third cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for her family's future and her children’s education. 

Betty is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Emeliana

texts.en:
Emeliana V., 32, is married and supports her family by operating two business ventures: ready-to-wear clothes and motorcycle transport. She lives in Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her ready-to-wear clothes and transport businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7,500. 

Emeliana is borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can purchase a motorcycle. This will be her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Emeliana aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Connie

texts.en:
Connie is a 30-year-old widow who supports her family by operating 2 businesses: a general store and a carinderia (a local eatery). She lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. Connie has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her two businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000. Connie is borrowing PHP 26,000 in order to fund her business operations. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Connie hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Amralt

texts.en:
Amralt, 36 years old, lives with her daughter and husband in the Suhbaatar district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She and her family live in their own house and enclosure.

Amralt operates a water trolley sales business. She began her business in 1998, selling the trolleys in the Narantuul market. Her husband helps her with the business and in taking care of their 1-year-old daughter at home. Her husband makes the water trolleys himself with iron. Amralt is a hardworking and friendly woman who says, " I'm very satisfied in my business." She is requesting 2,300,000 MNT to buy iron and rubber to make the water trolleys to increase her working capital.

loans.use: to buy iron and rubber to produce trolleys

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda S. is from the village of Brgy. Banganan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old, married and has 3 adult-aged children. Luzviminda owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzviminda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Luzviminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Esterlina

texts.en:
Esterlina is a 38-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a business selling fish and fruits. She lives in Bago City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. Esterlina now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000. Esterlina is borrowing PHP 15,000 in order to purchase more inventory to sell. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Esterlina hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is a married woman who lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a furniture making business. Her husband, Edgar M., 40 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living. They have 5 children aged between 4 and 17 years old.

Delia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon and her own efforts, Delia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 3rd loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to fund her business operations in order to save up for her children's education. Delia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Celestina

texts.en:
During her 4 years as a member of ASHI, Celestina has performed very well and ASHI trusts her to repay her loans. When she became a member of Kiva's field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she always used her loans for her farming business, hoping someday that it would grow bigger and give her family enough income for their expenses and, most importantly, for her grandchildren's education.

Celestina wants her grandchildren to finish their studies until they earn a degree for their better futures. For this reason, she never stops finding ways to get her business to grow. Celestina is asking for a new loan for additional capital for her farming business. She will buy items needed to improve the farm, such as fertilizers, insecticides and other supplies.

Celestina is glad for the secured opportunity of taking this loan and for your support and inspiration. Celestina's biggest dream is to have rice production someday. She hopes to maintain a long-term sustainable farming business. Celestina’s one hope and goal in life is to raise her family out of poverty

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, insecticides and other supplies.

loans.name: Eufracia

texts.en: Eufracia is a married woman who lives in Toboso, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a General (Sari-sari) Store business. Her husband Francisco, who is 56 years old, helps in his wife's business activities. They have 6 children who are between 35 to 46 years old. Eufracia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1996 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 21 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Eufracia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 22nd loan, she is borrowing 19,500 PHP, which she intends to use to fund  her business operations so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Eufracia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: As funds for her business operations

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza F. is from the village of Brgy. Bangana, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Flordeliza is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Flordeliza owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Flordeliza has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Flordeliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flordeliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Flordeliza is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Flordeliza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Dorcas is borrowing 15,000 PHP so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Dorcas aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman who lives in Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: hog raising, running a general store, and managing a sugarcane plantation. Her husband Francisco, who is 52 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps with his wife’s business activities. They have four children who are between 24 to 32 years old. All of them have family of their own.  

Josephine joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Josephine has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 21,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 5,000 PHP and uplifted the family’s standard of living.  This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP to buy feed and fertilizer to continue to save for the future expansion of her hog raising business. Josephine is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy K. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kamuli in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Prossy has a business selling charcoal, which she has run for three years. She has a second business selling food (bananas).
To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more charcoal and bananas for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Prossy hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself. In the future, she hopes to become a doctor after completing her studies.
Prossy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to protect herself from HIV/AIDS, and allowing her to take loans, which have improved her business.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and bananas for resale

loans.name: Arsenia

texts.en:
Arsenia D. C. is from the village of Brgy. Banganan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old. Arsenia is married and has 4 school-aged children. She makes a living buying and selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Arsenia has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Arsenia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Arsenia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan, her third, was used to purchase additional products to sell. Arsenia is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her immediate family members. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing new items to expand product offerings

loans.name: Stephen Njenga

texts.en:
Stephen Njenga K. is 33 years old. He runs a medical clinic in Mwandoni and has been in this business for the last three years. This will be his first loan from KADET LTD. Stephen plans to use the loan to purchase medicine for the clinic. 

The anticipated profits will be directed into the replenishment of stock in his business. His hopes and dreams are to improve his living standards.

loans.use: To purchase medicine for his clinic

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Tough, hardworking and a good mother of three are characteristics that describe Divina, a 39 year old woman. She is married to Jericko, who is also 39, and they work closely together as fishermen. The couple is motivated to work harder by their children, who live with them. 

Divina joined ASHI in 2008 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in income generating activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASHI. Divina is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase additional fishing net, fish traps, and provide working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to expand. 

With the chance given to her family by the Kiva partner ASHI, Divina believes that she is getting closer to attaining her family’s dreams. Divina’s dreams are for her three children to experience a decent way of living, out of poverty.  Additionally, she hopes that, through her determination, her business will be successful.

loans.use: to buy fishing net, fish traps, and provide working capital

loans.name: Zosima

texts.en:
Zosima L. is from the village of Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 39 years old. Zosima is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Zosima owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Zosima has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Zosima joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zosima is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Zosima from ASKI. loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kamuli in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Sylvia has a business selling cow's milk, which she has run for one year. She has a second business selling plastic jerrycans.
To help expand her business, Sylvia has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more cow's milk and more jerrycans for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Sylvia hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to own a small retail shop that sells sugar and soap. Sylvia is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by assisting her in improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase more cow's milk and jerrycans for resale

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy K. and her husband, Mr. Bunny Noun (pictured together), live in a village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1995 and have four children: one son and three daughters. 

Chanthy is a weaver. Her husband is a mechanic. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting and to purchase weaving materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting and purchase weaving materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina V. is from the village of Brgy. Banganan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 40 years old. Gina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Gina has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gina is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Gina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offerings

loans.name: Phallin

texts.en:
Mrs. Phallin Y. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Sokhom Noun, live in a village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. The couple has been married since 1996 and has four children: three sons and one daughter. 

Mrs. Phallin Y. runs a grocery store at home in the village and also rents a space in her house to garment-factory workers. She has requested a Kiva loan two times; she now is asking for another loan of $300 to purchase grocery items for her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her inventory

His previous loan of PHP 14,000, which he paid off well within its term, was just another step in his journey toward economic freedom. Efren hopes to elevate his family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Lai

texts.en:
Mrs. Lai E. is 46 years old and her husband, Mr. Phat Ban, is 48 years old (both are in the photo). They live along National Road Number 1 about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. The couple has been farming for 15 years. They have been married since 1987 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Two are in school, one has full-time employment and another one is still young. 

Besides farming, Lai also grows flowers and buys some flowers from the fellow villagers for resale in the Phnom Penh market. 

She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to get work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to get work

loans.name: Jacklin

texts.en:
Jacklin L. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kamuli in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Jacklin has a brick-making business, which she has run for one year.
To help expand her business, Jacklin has requested a loan of 100,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more firewood for firing the bricks and to pay her workers. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Jacklin hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family. In the future, she hopes to own another business selling fish.
Jacklin is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her standard of living (for example, having good clothes to wear and eating good food).

loans.use: To purchase more firewood for firing bricks, and pay her workers

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is a farmer from the town of Litein in in the Rift Valley in Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for ten years and currently employs two farmhands. His farm produces milk and tea, which are all sold locally.   Joel is 53 years old and married.  He has 5 school-aged children who all attend school.  He depends on the income from his farm to cater for the needs of his family.

Joel has requested a loan of 45,000KES through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help him pay the school fees for his children and expand his business. 

His major business challenges have been the lack of adequate animal feed and the unreliable artificial insemination services. He would like to increase the number of his dairy cows to fifteen and build a zero grazing unit in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mr. Chanthy S. is 24 years old.  He lives with wife and mother in a village along the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. He has been married since 2007 and does not yet have any children.
  
Chanthy drives a horse cart in his village and his wife works as a weaver. Chanthy is asking for his first loan of $800 to purchase weaving materials for his wife’s weaving business. He will also use a part of the loan to help his mother in her farming business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials and fund a farming operation

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a married woman who lives in Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, a sugarcane plantation, and a rice field. 

Her husband Ramelo, who is 40 years old, works as a jeepney driver to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 3 to 15 years old; two of them are currently going to school. 

Susan joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Susan has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 9,500 PHP, raising the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 7th loan, she is borrowing 23,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy stock for the store and fertilizer for the rice and sugarcane. She wants to continue to save up for future education costs and family needs. 

Susan is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a resident of Nyamira Town in Western Kenya. She is married with five children, aged between fifteen and two – four of them are now in school. She has been doing mixed farming for twelve years, selling her produce of maize, beans, sorghum and tea at the local market.

She has requested a loan of KES 45,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She believes this loan will generate enough income to pay for the education of her children as well as improve their living standards. She is optimistic she will be able to buy more dairy cows and start a wholesale business in the future. Her challenges in business are fluctuating market prices and hailstorms which destroy the crops before harvest.

loans.use: Purchase and insurance of a dairy cow

loans.name: Batgerel

texts.en: Batgerel, 35, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. Her older daughter and son attend a local school. Batgerel began her business by growing and then selling vegetables at a local market in 2003. In 2008, she and her husband started a taxi business that they operate in the winter time. Batgerel also makes deels, a Mongolian traditional handmade coat, and sells them to people who live in the countryside, far from the market. As a result of their hard work, the family bought a house for 8,000,000 MNT in 2010. Batgerel is a hardworking and active person who says, " I do several things at the same time because I like to keep myself busy. I am planning to operate my handmade clothing business." She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to buy more materials to make deels.

loans.use: to buy more materials

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
Ma. Fe A., 41 years old, is a very industrious mother from Talisay, Pandan, Antique, Philippines. She is married to a very supportive husband, Ceriaco A. Jr., and they are blessed with four children: Gerald, Gerryl, Kenneth and Kenny John, who are all studying. Ma. Fe believes that children are really the future of the land and that this future could be attained through education, the best weapon to combat poverty. Despite poverty, Ma. Fe and her husband really work hard just to earn an income to send their children to school.

This couple earns a living through their tricycle business and Ma. Fe has a variety store situated at Pandan Public Market.  As of now, this couple has already repaid their loan and Ma. Fe is proposing another loan in the amount of PHP 24,000 to be used as additional capital for her business. Ma. Fe's greatest dream is that all of her children finish their studies until college so that they will get better jobs. She also plans to expand her store if she gets more capital so that she will have a greater income.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en:

With the help of her loan from BRAC, Bridget hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food for her family. In the future, Bridget hopes to expand her business further.
Bridget is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future and taught her new games such as netball and carrom board game.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal for resale

loans.name: Chrin

texts.en:
Mr. Chrin N. and his wife, Mrs. Oun Prach, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  They have been married since 1993 and have two children – one son and one daughter, all of whom are in school. 

Chrin drives a Tuk Tuk taxi in Phnom Penh. His wife is a weaver. In December 2008, he asked for a Kiva loan to buy a second hand Tuk Tuk. Unfortunately, because it was old, it has now broken down again.  Therefore, he is asking for another loan of $600 to buy a new Tuk Tuk (not second hand).

loans.use: To purchase new Tuk Tuk.
