loans.name: Yudaya

texts.en:
Yudaya N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Yudaya has a business selling clothes, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Yudaya has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase clothes for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Yudaya hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to go back to school.
Yudaya is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save money, which will help her return to school.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Sarath

texts.en:
Mr. Sarath P., 29, is a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Sreylai Chueng, 28, is a garment factory worker. They have been married since 2005 and have one young son.  

They are currently living with his parents in a village along National Road Number Two, about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh City. He now wants to live in his own home and is asking for his first loan of $500 for build a house for himself and his wife.

loans.use: To add to his own money to build a house for himself and his wife

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a 49-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 businesses: ready-to-wear clothes and pants and rice retailing. She lives in Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. Josephine has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her two businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. Josephine is borrowing PHP 26,000 in order to purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Josephine hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en:
Doreen N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Doreen has a business selling fish, which she has run for three years.
To help expand her business, Doreen has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase fish for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Doreen hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself. In the future, she hopes to study business administration at university.
Doreen is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her life-planning skills, which guide her during decision-making.

loans.use: To purchase fish for resale

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is married and lives in Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by running three small businesses: aquaculture, tailoring and raising livestock. Her husband, Hernanie E., who is 60 years old, works as a laborer. They have four children who range in age from 26 to 34. Virginia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because wanted a better life for her family. With the help of her 14 previous loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Virginia has been achieving this goal. Her most recent loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000 and meant improvements to her family's life. She is applying for a new loan, her 15th, for PHP 13,000, which she intends to use to expand her aquaculture business and thereby help pay for her children's education and for home repairs. Virginia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its poverty alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To expand a small aquaculture business

loans.name: Chreal

texts.en:
Mrs. Chreal A. (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Phal Proeung, have been married since 1984.  They have two married children – one son and one daughter. Their son lives outside the family home while their daughter and her husband are still living with them.

Chreal weaves mosquito nets and scarves. Her husband assists his wife in this business in addition to his farming work. Chreal is requesting a loA. of $700 to purchase cotton threads to continue her weaving work.

loans.use: To purchase cotton threads to weave mosquito nets and scarves

loans.name: Juvidita

texts.en:
Juvidita T. is 44 years old and lives in Nauring, Pandan, Antique, Philippines. She is married to Rey T. and they have four children. Their oldest child, John Rey, is 18 years old while their youngest, Karl Anthony, is four. They are all still in school. She makes a living by raising livestock, while her husband works as a fisherman. Since all of their children are still in school, they must work hard to meet their daily expenses. 

Juvidita has been an active member of ASHI Antique North West Branch since 2005. She is a model member, and is widely respected for her hard work and many dreams. She has recently finished paying back her last loan, and is applying for a new one for PHP 20,000 to expand her livestock business. 

She dreams that through hard work and her membership in ASHI, all of her children will complete their studies and get good jobs. She also hopes to earn enough money to renovate her house and make her family more financially stable.

loans.use: To expand a small livestock business

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson is a father of five children, aged between twenty five and seventeen.  Currently two of his children are still attending school.  

Nelson has been practicing mixed farming in his hometown of Nyamira in Western Kenya for eighteen years.  He sells his bananas to the local market and tea to the Kenya Tea Development Authority.  He also trades in timber to earn additional income.  He employs three farmhands to help with labour on the farm.

Nelson has requested a loan of 35,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow.  He intends to use the income generated to expand his farming business.  

Nelson sees labour costs as his main challenge in business, due to the high rates.  He also wishes to get more training in farming and have access to more loan services.

loans.use: Purchase and insurance of a dairy cow

loans.name: Florina

texts.en:
Florina is married and lives in Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fishing and a livestock business. Her husband, William Z., is 36 years old and works as a backhoe operator. They have four children who range in age from 8 to 10. Florina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of four previous loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has succeeded in slowly lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her last loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, and brought an improved life to her family. Now, for her fifth loan, she would like to borrow PHP 12,000 to buy new fishing equipment. This will allow her to increase her income further and continue to save for her children's education. Florina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its poverty alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy new fishing equipment

loans.name: Muhunga Abesigwa Group

texts.en:
A. Matayo is the leader of a lending group called the Muhunga Abesigwa group. He is 35 years old and is married with two children.  He owns a small restaurant in Muhunga Trading Centre.   Matayo offers mainly local food and tea to his customers, who are mostly workers and residents around the trading centre. From the restaurant, he is able to earn 25,000 UGX daily. 

Matayo says that he is also involved in crop farming, from which he grows food for home consumption and for sale. He is a gentle and hardworking man and he hopes for a stable family and a continuously growing business.

loans.use: To buy foodstuff for restaurant

loans.name: Chanthol

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthol S. (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Ty Bouy, are vegetable farmers. They live along National Road Number Six about 18 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

This couple had previously received and repaid a loan from Kiva. They are now applying for another loan of $350 to continue their business by purchasing seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To continue farming business

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is a resident of Nyamira town in Western Kenya.  He has been practicing mixed farming, concentrating mostly on tea, for over ten years. He is married and has six children. He sells his tea products to the local market.

Fred has requested a loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo, a Kiva partner, to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He reckons that the dairy cow will enable him to generate enough income to pay school fees for this children. He is focusing on buying three more dairy cows to improve on his milk production in the next 5 years. He also intends to purchase a motor vehicle in the future to help transport his produce to the market.

Fred sees unpredictable weather conditions – especially heavy rains and droughts, coupled with the lack of farm supplies like fertilizer, as the major challenges in this business.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new fishing equipment

loans.name: Dorca

texts.en:
Dorca is a resident of Nyamira town in Western Kenya.  She is a mother of four children, aged between thirteen and five. She practices mixed farming, selling her produce of tea, eggs, milk and vegetables to the local market. She employs one farmhand.

Dorca has requested a loan for 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She plans to use the income from this loan to pay school fees for her four children and to improve their living standards. She is also focusing on expanding her poultry business and venture into the wholesale business for eggs.

She notes that diseases are her greatest challenges, especially for her poultry business.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Chandoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chandoeun C. (pictured) is 31 years old.  Her husband, Mr. Ly Phoeun, is 43 years old.  They have been married for ten years and have two children – one son and one daughter, both of whom are in school. The family lives in a suburb approximately 25 kilometeres from Phnom Penh.

Chandoeun is a garment factory worker. Her husband is a construction worker. She is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to get to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to go to work

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma is separated form her spouse and lives in Bago City, Negros Occidental, where she earns a living by buying and selling rice. She has a child who is 26 years old. She joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she wanted a better life for family. With the help of 17 previous loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Emma has been slowly lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) helped increase her monthly profits to PHP 10,000, and that meant a higher living standard for her family. She is applying for her 18th loan, for PHP 19,500, to buy more rice to sell because this will allow her to save more money and create a prosperous future for herself and her daughter. Emma is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) woman who is following an honorable path to the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through its poverty-alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending group on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: To buy more rice to sell to her customers

loans.name: Reziel

texts.en:
Reziel is 34-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a sari-sari (variety) store. She lives in Bago City, Negros Occidental. Reziel has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Reziel is borrowing PHP 12,000 in order to purchase more inventory to sell. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Reziel hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to buy additional stock

loans.name: Ol

texts.en:
Mr. Ol L. is 33 years old.  His wife, Mrs. Chansoul Kong, is 27 years old.  They have been married since 1999 and have three children – two sons and one daughter, all of whom are in school. They live along National Road Number Five, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Ol is a remoque taxi driver (a remoque is a motorcycle with a trailer in the back). His wife is a garment factory worker. He is asking for a loan of $1,200 to repair his motorcycle and trailer and to repair the house where he lives.

loans.use: To repair vehicle and repair house

loans.name: Zeny

texts.en:
Zeny is a married woman who lives in Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three businesses: buying and selling sugarcane crops, tricycle transport and farming. Her husband, Wilson E. Sr., 51 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living. They have three children between the ages of 23 and 27, all of whom currently attend school.

Zeny joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon and through her own efforts, Zeny has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,000, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 27,000, which she intends to use as additional capital to buy and sell sugarcane crops. Her goal is to save up for her children's education and for the improvement of her businesses. Zeny is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to buy and sell sugarcane crops

loans.name: Fatina

texts.en:
Fatina M. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has no children. Fatina has a tailoring business, which she has run for three years.
To help expand her business, Fatina has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase material to make clothes for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Fatina hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to own a small retail shop that sells sugar and soap.
Fatina is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future and taught her new games.

loans.use: To purchase material to make clothes for resale

loans.name: Sisa

texts.en:
Sisa is a 38-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a sari-sari store and a fishing business. She lives in Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1990 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her two businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000. Sisa is borrowing PHP 19,000 in order to purchase more inventory to sell. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Sisa hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Hadbaatar

texts.en: Mr. Hadbaatar is 29 years old. He lives with his wife and two sons, aged 3 and 7, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He used to work as a driver for an exploration company but lost his job due to job cuts. In May 2010, he started running a taxi business using his family car.  His family does not have a place to live and currently live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, on his brother's plot of land.  Hadbaatar’s goal is to have a proper job and buy a house for his family.  He is requesting a loan to buy spare parts and to service his car.

loans.use: To buy spare parts and service car

loans.name: Buhumuliro Bahereza Group

texts.en:
T. Monday is the leader of the Buhumuriro Bahereza group in Kyenjojo. He is 45 years old, married, and has 5 children, aged 20 to 10. 

Monday has a business selling produce such as maize, grains, beans, millet and matooke to transporters from Kampala and Mbarara. He is able to make 40,000 UGX in weekly profits.  He is happy that he can get some of his supplies from his own garden since he is also a farmer. 

Monday has been in this business for 8 years, after moving from a fish selling business in Matsyoro. His dream is to be able to have multiple businesses – one for each season, since most of the businesses are seasonal.

loans.use: To purchase grains

loans.name: Serafina

texts.en:
Serafina T. is from the village of Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 47 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Serafina owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Serafina has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Serafina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Serafina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Serafina is requesting a new loan of 21,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Serafina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

location.town: Brgy.Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr: Odette N. est commerçante, et client d’ACB depuis 2009.  Elle est veuve, née au Congo (RDC), et elle a 8 enfants entre 12 ans et 28 ans, et 3 personnes en charge.  Deux de ses enfants vont à l’école, et elle a fini 6 ans d’école primaire.  Elle va utiliser son prêt pour l’achat d’une grande quantité de pommes de terre, et pour acheter d’électricité pour son deuxième business d’électricité.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’augmenter  son business, est aller à l’extérieur du pays pour amener une grande quantité des pommes de terre pour les vendre au marché.  Elle voudrait augmenter la quantité vendue de pommes de terre, avoir un bon foyer, et satisfaire les besoins de son foyer.  Elle voudrait aussi éduquer ses enfants jusqu'à l’université.
texts.en:
Odette N., a merchant, has been a member of ACB since 2009. Born in the Congo (DRC), she is a widow with eight children whose ages range between 12 and 28. She also has three other people in her care. She completed six years of primary school, and two of her children go to school. 

She plans to use her loan to purchase a large quantity of potatoes and to get electricity for her second business. Her growth strategy is to bolster her activities by travelling abroad to acquire large quantities of potatoes for sale at the market. She wants to increase her sales of potatoes, keep a good home, and meet the needs of her household. She also wants her children to pursue university studies.

loans.use: To buy potatoes, electricity for sale

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima M. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Alima has a business selling clothes, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Alima has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Alima hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to study computer studies.
Alima is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her positive behaviors (for example, changing her lifestyle to protect herself from HIV/AIDS).

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Josiah

texts.en:
Josiah has been doing mixed farming for 24 years and produces coffee, bananas, macadamia and miraa (a plant containing a stimulant), which are all sold locally. He also earns income from his butchery in the same location.

He has requested a loan of 42,000 Kenyan shillings through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable him to build a modern house to live in. He also hopes that in five years' time, he will have constructed residential houses and acquired more dairy cows.

Josiah is 47 years old and married with one adult child.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia E. is from the village of Brgy. Kirang, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Virginia owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for breeding. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Virginia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Virginia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase feed and other supplies

loans.name: Nosendewi Ene

texts.en:
Nosendewi Ene M.  is 23 years old.  She is married and supports ten people.  Nosendewi is a farmer and has been farming on her own piece of land for the last eight years.

She learned about KADET LTD from other women who are registered with KADET. This will be her second loan, which she will use to buy maize seeds and fertilizers and to hire manpower for planting. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to advance her farming activity and educate her siblings.

Nosendewi's dream is to own a large piece of land for farming. She is a assiduous woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: to buy maize seeds & fertilizers and hire labor for planting

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Madina has a small retail shop business that sells sugar and soap, which she has run for three years.
To help expand her business, Madina has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase sugar and soap for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Madina hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.
Madina is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has aided her prospects for the future by helping her to be hardworking. She will now work hard to see that she completes paying back her loan.

loans.use: To purchase sugar and soap for resale

loans.name: Buhumuriro Bashubuzi Kweterana Group

texts.en:
Betty R. is the leader of the Buhumuriro Bashubuzi Kweterana group in Kyenjojo. She is 38 years old, married, and has 6 children. 

Betty has a retail shop in Busingye that has been in existence for over 2 years, in addition to her crop farming business. Her customers buys mostly daily home use products, and from these sales she is able to make 30,000 UGX in weekly profit. 

Betty is a self starter, hard worker and innovator.  These traits have enabled her to succeed.  Her dream is to have a stable family and a continuously growing business. She needs a loan to be able to buy more soap, sugar, flour, dry beans to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy soap, sugar, flour, dry beans to sell

loans.name: Silvano

texts.en:
Silvano is a farmer from Nkubu town in Eastern Kenya. He is 65 years old, married, and has 7 adult children. He has been farming for the last twenty years and produces maize, beans, miraa and milk, which he sells both to the local market and through Kenya Cooperative Creameries.

Silvano has requested a loan of 40,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to upgrade his dairy farm. He intends to use this loan to construct a better zero grazing unit and to buy animal feeds. He says this loan will help improve his farm production, which will boost his income and enable him to employ people on his farm.

loans.use: To upgrade dairy farm

loans.name: Dieudonne

texts.fr: Dieudonné B.  est marié et il a deux enfants entre 1 et 4 enfants, et  Il a une éducation primaire.  Il est commerçant avec sa machine pour laver et sécher les habits. Il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter une pièce de rechange de cette machine qui a été  endommagé,  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’épargner pour augmenter l’activité et se procurer le marché(les clients).  Il voudrait avoir une maison, et la réhabiliter.
texts.en: Dieudonné B. is married and has two children, between 1 and 4 [years of age]. He has primary education. He provides laundry services using his washer and dryer machine. He will use his loan to purchase a replacement part for the machine, which is damaged. His business strategy is to save money in order to expand his business and attract more clients. He would like to buy a house and furnish it.

loans.use: Purchasing replacement parts to repair his washer/dryer

loans.name: Megzem

texts.en:
Mrs. Megzem G., 24 years old, lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The couple is newly wed and currently they live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, on Megzem’s brother’s piece of land. They are planning to buy a piece of land in the near future. Megzem’s husband works for a private company as a truck driver.

Megzem rents an area inside a small shop, where she sells fruits and vegetables. Megzem is an accountant; however, she could not find a job in her specialization. Her profession helps a lot in her business. She buys her products from the Narantuul wholesale market, where she has contracted suppliers. Due to the approaching Lunar New Year’s celebration, Megzem is planning to increase her sales by increasing her stock and variety of products.

loans.use: to increase her stock and product variety for the Lunar New Year's celebration

loans.name: Consolata

texts.en:
Consolata K. is a 55-year-old farmer from Nkubu town in Eastern Kenya. She has been in the farming business for 28 years and employs two farmhands. Her farm produces coffee, milk, mangoes and milk, which are all sold locally. She also operates a clinic in the same region.

Consolata has requested a loan of 47,250 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and  insure a dairy cow. This will help increase her income through the sale of milk. Her major challenges have been pests and diseases, which affect her animals and crops, and the high cost of animal feeds.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Bayartogtoh

texts.en: Bayartogtoh, 55, is married and lives with her husband and children in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her youngest son attends college in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. In 2005, she began her clothing business at a stall in a local market; she has also been selling the clothes to people who live far away in the countryside by using her car. She purchases the clothing from Erlian, a city on the border with China. She is a very reliable customer of our bank and has been operating her business with no problems. She has received about 20 start-up loans from our bank and has consistently paid each back on time. For a woman of her age, she is energetic enough to continue to operate her business. Bayartogtoh is a hardworking and kind person who says, "I wish to expand my business by any means and open my own store in the future." She is requesting a loan of 2,100,000 Mongolian tugriks to purchase more clothing from China for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Nanita

texts.en: Nanita E. is from the village of Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 41 years old. Nanita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Nanita runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Nanita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Nanita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nanita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Nanita is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Nanita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

location.town: Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah Nabuto lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, three of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren).     

Sarah has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works one day out of every week. Sarah sells her products at home, by means of wholesale/retail. 

Sarah has requested  a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through selling firewood. The main business challenges for Sarah include defaulters and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van to ease transport and also to educate her children up to university. 

Sarah lives in a home that she rents/owns; she doesn't have access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Duncan

texts.en:
Duncan has been in the farming business for thirty years now.  He produces bananas, milk and maize, which are all sold locally. He is also employed as a driver.

Duncan has requested a loan of 47,250 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve the livelihood for his family and pay school fees for his youngest child. 

In the future, he would like to acquire 3 quality dairy cows and buy land to put up residential houses.  His primary challenges have been diseases and the lack of artificial insemination services.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Jolly

texts.en:
Jolly S. is from the village of Banganan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 45 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jolly owns and operates a a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Jolly has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 5,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jolly joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jolly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory. Jolly is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Jolly from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Lencer Adhiambo

texts.en:
For 18 years, Lencer Adhiambo has been selling fish in Dandora Estate, a highly populated area.  She has very many customers and earns a monthly profit of KES 5,000. Lencer is 42 years old, married to Peter, and they have four school-going children.

Lencer is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a client who is a registered member of KADET. She intends to use the loan to buy more fish to sell to her customers. With the anticipated profit, she will add more stock of fish and pay school fees for her children.

In the future, she desires to grow her business and start supplying fish to the hotels. Lencer is a hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell

loans.name: Nekusua Enole

texts.en:
Nekusua Enole D. is 40 years old. She is married and is a mother of eight.  Nekususa is a mixed farmer who has been farming on her own piece of land for the last eighteen years.

Nekusua learned about KADET LTD from other women in her area of residence who are in group registered with KADET. This will be her second loan,  which she plans to spend on seeds and fertilizer. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Nekusua's dream is to build a rental houses and buy cows for rearing. She is a hardworking woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Erdenebat

texts.en:
Erdenebat, 32, is married and lives with his wife and two sons in the Uvurhangai Province of Mongolia. They live in a ger (traditional felt house) on a small plot of land that they have owned for the past ten years. He is an electrician and his wife is a seamstress. 

Erdenebat operates two kinds of business. He started his clothes trading business in 2002, and later began his carpentry business in 2007. He now rents a space and operates his business in a Local Business Development Center. He purchases the wood from nearby vendors in the countryside. 

Erdenebat is a hardworking, modest and warmhearted person who says, "I want to save money in order to be able to provide the possibility for my sons to get a college education in the future and I also wish to open my own workshop." He wants to purchase more clothing from China for his business clothing trading business. He is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to purchase more clothing from Erlian, a border city of China with Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Philipina

texts.en:
Forty-year-old Philipina is a married mother of 5 school-aged children, who are all attending school. She is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya.  She has been in the farming business for 15 years and produces eggs, bananas, and milk, which are all sold locally.

She has requested a loan for 60,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to expand her poultry farm. The extra income from this loan investment will help her pay school fees for her children. She would like to have more than 3,000 chickens in the next five years.  In her business, she faces the challenge of diseases,  which affects her production.

loans.use: To expand poultry farm

loans.name: Ann Kijoolu Ene

texts.en:
Ann Kijoolu Ene K. is 26 years old.  She is married to Nesoore K. and supports five people in her family.  Ann is a businesswoman who owns a curio shop,  which she has been operating for the last seven years.

Ann learned about KADET LTD from groups registered with KADET. This will be her first loan, which she plans to use to buy more stock of curios.  Her curio business has been doing well in the area due to the presence of tourists. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to improve the living standards for her family and offer good things to her children.

Ann's dream is to prosper in the business of curios. She is a punctilious lady who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: To buy curios to resell

loans.name: Monhtuya

texts.en:
Monhtuya, 33, is married and lives with her husband and two daughters in Bayanhongor Province of Mongolia. They live in a ger (Mongolian nomadic housing tent) which they bought four years ago along with the land. Her husband is her co-worker and sells clothing to the people in the countryside who are not able to reach the market everyday. 

They used to live in the countryside herding livestock before they came to the province center. She began her clothing trading business in 2007 by renting an outdoor stall at a local market. Now she rents a kiosk. She began her retail trading operation with working capital of 1,000,000 MNT and was able to increase it up to 4,000,000 MNT. She plans to diversify the variety of the goods and pays attention to its quality as people prefer higher quality products these days. She used to purchase her goods from Erlian, which is a city near the Chinese border. Now she prefers to bring clothing from Beijing, the capital of China, as there is more variety and higher quality clothing there. 

She is an open-minded and sociable person who says, "We want to make more profit and build our own house on the land we own now by next year." She is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to purchase more clothing for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Kosiom Ole

texts.en:
Kosiom Ole M. is 24 years old, married and supports four people in the family. Kosiom is a farmer who raises maize on his own piece of land, which he has been doing for the last 6 years.

He learned about KADET from credit officers through their marketing. This will be his third loan. Kosiom plans to purchase farm inputs. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming and also to pay school fees.

Kosiom's dream is to practice large-scale farming and attain financial independence. He is a conscientious man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Moussokoro

texts.fr:
Moussokoro D.,  âgée de 49 ans, mariée et mère de 5 filles réside chez son père à Mancourani I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Moussokoro D. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activité sans succès, s’est initiée il maintenant  5 ans à la fabrique de savons qu’elle a appris auprès d’une amie. Elle mène son activité à son domicile de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de trois années, avec qui elle a bénéficié cinq prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association ASSURANCE de Mancourani I). Ainsi, elle est à son premier prêt individuel qui lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de roulement afin d’acheter les matières premières nécessaires. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce  premier prêt 1 fût d’huile de coton, 1 fût de déchets d’huile de coton (pâtes noires), 3 sacs de soude caustique, 1 paquet de parfums et 2 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe. Elle achetée ses matières premières sur place et à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso). Elle fabrique ses savons et les découpe en morceaux afin de les revendre, en demi gros aux revendeurs et en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes de sa localité.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 95 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement  pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Moussokoro D., who is 49 years old and the mother of 5 girls, lives with her father in Mancouranin 1, one of the districts of Sikasso (in the third administrative region of Mali).
Moussokoro D. after having many unsuccessful activities, learnt how to make soap from a friend 5 years ago .She runs her business from her home in Sikasso and is much in demand from her customers due to the high quality of her goods.To satisfy her growing clientele, three years ago she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation, with whom she has benefitted from five interdependent loans (group loans) with a women’s association in her neighbourhood (Mancourani I Insurance Association) thus this is her first individual loan which will enable her to increase her working capital in order to purchase the necessary raw materials.
With this first credit she plans to buy 1 barrel of cotton seed oil, 1 barrel of cotton seed oil scrap (black pastes), 3 bags of caustic soda, 1 package of perfume, and 2 cartloads of firewood. She buys her raw materials locally and at Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso).She makes the soaps and cuts them into pieces in order to sell them  half wholesale to dealers, and retail to a clientele that is mainly made up of women in her neighbourhood.
With this loan she hopes to make a monthly profit of 95 000 FCFA which she will use mainly to contribute to family expenses, to pay the interest of her loan and she will invest the remainder in her business.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for the manufacture of soap

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia N. lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is in school. 

Sylvia has a business of selling fruits and vegetables. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works seven days out of every week.  Sylivia sells her products from home, by means of retail.  

Sylvia has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more passion fruits. The main business challenges for Sylvia include seasonality and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van to ease transport and also to buy a plot of land and build her own house.   

Sylvia lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity but has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of passion fruits

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née le 26 Décembre 1963 à N’Kourala préfecture de Sikasso, Mariam Koné est veuve et mère de quatre enfants dont 2 garçons et 2 filles. Elle réside avec ses  propres enfants et des enfants adoptifs au quartier Médine de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Mariam K. après avoir avoir perdu son époux il y’a dix sept ans, s’est initiée au  commerce  d’articles divers tels l’achat et la vente de condiments alimentaires. Elle vend au nouveau de marché dont elle dispose d’un magasin et table où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux ans. Ainsi elle a bénéficié  de deux prêts qui ont été tous remboursés avec succès. Alors dans but de toujours mieux se relancer dans même activité, elle sollicite ce troisième prêt qui lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour pouvoir acheter, 15 sacs de pomme de terre, 12 sacs d’oignons de graines différentes et un important stock de condiments alimentaires (gombo, sel de cuisine, concentrée de tomates, etc).
Ces marchandises  qu’elle achète sur place avec les paysans producteurs venant des villages environnants sont ramenées dans les marchés hebdomadaires de Yorosso et Kouri, vers la frontière Mali-Burkina Faso pour être vendues en détail  et en gros au comptant les jours de foire à une clientèle composée essentiellement de forains.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on December 26, 1963 in N’Kourala, in Sikasso prefecture, Ms. Mariam Koné is a widow and the mother of two boys and two girls.  She resides with her own children and adopted children in the Médine district in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having lost her husband seventeen years ago, she got started in commerce, the buying and selling of a variety of items such as condiments. She sells at the new market where she has a store and a table. There, she is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her goods. 

To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, Mariam decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about two years ago. Thus, she has benefited from two loans, which have both been repaid successfully. And so, with the goal of reinvigorating the same business further, she is requesting this third loan, which will enable her to increase her working capital in order to buy:  15 sacks of potatoes, 12 sacks of onions, various grains, and a major stock of condiments (okra, kitchen salt, tomato paste, etc.) These goods, which she buys locally from peasant producers from surrounding villages, are taken to the weekly markets of Yorosso and Kouri, toward the Mali-Burkina Faso border, in order to be sold retail and wholesale to a customer base composed essentially of fair-goers paying cash on the days the fairs take place.  

With this loan, Mariam envisions making a monthly profit of 200,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase her working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to pay the loan interest.

loans.use: Buying condiments, potatoes, Maggie bouillon cubes, onoions, etc.

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Salimata T. est une femme mariée de 43 ans et mère de 4 enfants (3 garçons et 1 fille). Elle vit avec son époux  dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Fama, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Salimata T. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à la fabrique des savons traditionnels (savons noirs) il y a environ six années qu’elle a appris auprès d’une voisine. Elle mène son activité à son domicile de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de 3 années avec laquelle elle est à son 5ème prêt individuel, tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 16 futs de déchets d’huile de coton (pâtes noires), 8 sacs de soude caustique et 4 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe. Après fabrication des savons à base de déchets d’huile de coton et de soude caustique, elle les revend en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes de sa localité.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 240 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Salimata T., aged 43, is a married women and the mother of four children (three boys and a girl).  She lives with her husband in a large traditional family in Fama, the downtown of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  After having run many businesses unsuccessfully, Salimata became familiarized with making traditional soaps (black soap) about six years ago.  She learned this trade from a neighbor and operates out of her home in Sikasso, where she is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her products.

To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, Salimata decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over three years ago and is now on her fifth individual loan.  The previous loans have all been properly repaid.  With this new loan, she intends to buy 16 barrels of waste cotton oil (black paste), 8 sacks of caustic soda, and 4 cart loads of firewood.  After making the soap from the waste cotton oil and caustic soda, she sells it retail to a customer base composed generally of women in her town.

With this loan, Salimata envisions making a monthly profit of 240,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for increasing her working capital, helping to cover family expenses, and paying the loan interest.

loans.use: Buying waste cotton oil and caustic soda

loans.name: Parkire

texts.en:
Parkire O. is 27 years old, married and supports ten people in the family. Parkire is a farmer. He farms his own piece of land which he has done for the last seven years.

He learned about KADET from other men in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his third loan which he is planning to spend to buy eight bags of Kenya seed-certified wheat and eight bags of fertilizer. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to build a permanent home and expand his farming activity.

Parkire's dream is to construct rental houses. He is an industrious man who is determined to achieve his objectives.

loans.use: To buy eight bags of Kenya seed-certified wheat and eight bags of fertilizer

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria N. lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children, two of whom are in school.  

Gloria has a business of knitting sweaters. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Gloria sells her products from home. 

Gloria has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of threads and needles. She also generates additional income through part-time teaching. 

The main business challenges for Gloria include seasonality and the ever-increasing price of thread. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a cottage industry and also to buy a plot of land and build her own house. 

Gloria lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity but has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more thread and needles

loans.name: Siaka

texts.fr:
Né le 19 Avril 1978 à Sikasso ville, Monsieur Siaka  B. est marié et père de 2 enfants (1 garçon et 1 fille), il réside avec sa femme et ses enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle avec ses parents et ses frères à Lafiabougou, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur B. dans le souci de s’insérer dans le tissu économique, s’est initié à l’achat et à la vente d’articles de quincaillerie dont il dispose actuellement une boutique au grand marché de Sikasso. Il est beaucoup sollicité  pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus d’une année. Après un premier premier correctement remboursé, il est à son deuxième qui  permettra d’augmenter son fonds de commerce.
Avec ce  deuxième prêt , il compte acheter 20 cartons baquettes, 12 boîtes de colles, 15 paquets de peintures, 70 mètres de fil, 8 pelles, 5 piques, etc. Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes à Bamako avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des constructeurs de maison (architectes, entrepreneurs, maçons, etc.)
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on April 19, 1978 in Sikasso City, Mr. Siaka B. is a married man and a father of two children (a boy and a girl). He resides with his wife and children in a large traditional family with his parents and brothers in Lafiabougou, a suburb of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Wanting to enter the working world, Mr. B. got started in the buying and selling of hardware. He currently has a hardware store at the main market of Sikasso.  He is in high demand for the quality of his goods.  

To satisfy his burgeoning customer base, he decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over a year ago. After an initial loan, which was properly repaid, he is now on his second loan that will enable him to increase his working capital. 

With this second loan, he intends to buy 20 boxes of welding rods, 12 containers of glue, 15 packages of paint, 70 meters of wire, 8 shovels, 5 picks, etc.  He gets his supplies from wholesale merchants in Bamako and then sells them retail to a customer base composed generally of house builders (architects, entrepreneurs, masons, etc.) 

With this loan, he envisions making a monthly profit of 250,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for helping with family expenses and paying the loan interest.  The rest will be invested in his business.

loans.use: Buying hardware items

loans.name: Marima Korio

texts.en:
Marima Korio B. is 32 years old, married to Kimererio Marima, and a father of four school-aged children. He is a farmer. He raises maize on his own piece of land and has been doing so for the last 15 years.

He learned about KADET LTD from credit officers in their marketing. He plans to use his third loan to purchase farm inputs. He successfully paid the previous loans well and in time. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming and also to pay school fees.

Marima's dream is to do large-scale farming and attain financial independence. He is a diligent man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson M. O. is sixty years old and married.  His wife stays at home to take care of the household chores and they have eight children between the ages of thirty three years old and seventeen years old. 

Wilson sells newspapers to passerby near a stage at Kawangware in Nairobi.  He has been in this business for fourteen years now.  He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints.  He works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well.  He is using his loan of 50,000 KES to buy newspapers to grow his business by serving more people.  He hopes that in future, he will diversify his business by opening a general store.  He also sees himself buying a plot of land in which he will build a better home for his family.  He describes himself as patient and aggressive.

loans.use: To buy more newspapers for sale.

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex N. lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, two of whom are in school.  

Alex has a business of selling milk. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Alex sells her products door-to-door.    

Alex has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more jerrycans of milk. She also generates additional income through poultry farming. The main business challenges for Alex include debtors and the ever-increasing prices of milk.  

Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own milk coolers and also to buy a plot of land and build her own house.   

Alex lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity but has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of milk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Add more bricks to his shop

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school.  Madina has a retail shop. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Madina sells her products at the market, by means of retail. 

Madina has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerrycans of cooking oil. The main business challenges for Madina include debtors and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to educate her children up to university and also to be a wholesaler.   

Madina lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and cooking oil

loans.name: Gédéon

texts.fr: Gédéon H. est magasiner, et client d’ACB depuis 2009.  Il a 26 ans, et célibataire.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour payer les frais scolaires pour son petit frère, et louer une maison d’habitation.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est de continuer à bien exercice son travail, et avoir la discipline de travail pour ne pas perdre son boulot.  Il voudrait épargner pour réserver l’argent qui peut l’aider en case d’un problème improvisé. Il voudrait aussi se marier pour fonder sa propre famille, et aider ses parents à réhabiliter leur maison.
texts.en: Gédéon H. is a warehouseman and a client of ACB since 2009.  He is 26 years old and single. He is going to use his loan to pay the tuition fees for his younger brother and to rent a house to live in. His business strategy is to continue doing his work well and have high work discipline in order to avoid losing his job. He would to put money away as savings for emergencies. He would like to be able to marry and start his own family and help his parents furnish their house.

loans.use: Pay tuition   for his younger brother and rental fees on a house

loans.name: Gilbert

texts.en:
Gilbert is a dairy farmer in the town of Litein in Kenya's Rift Valley. He has been in the farming business for six years and he sells his milk to Brookside Company in Litein. He also earns income from his cybercafe in the same region. 

He recently repaid a previous loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo.  He has requested a loan of 80,000 KES to buy more milk for sale. This loan will enable him to expand his dairy business and to earn more income that will assist him in meeting his family's needs. He hopes that he will be able to fully establish his business in the next 5 years.

Gilbert is 30 years old and married, with one child who is now 9 months old.

loans.use: To increase his stock of milk to resell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 43-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and three young children who are attending school. He has been working in the agriculture field for 10 years and in 2006 he bought his own land and started to cultivate vegetables and sell them in his town and its surroundings.  He is the only income provider of the family.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $700 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to perform needed maintenance on the water canal so that he can guarantee that the vegetables receive the water well and grow well as a result.

loans.use: to perform the needed maintenance on the water canal

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 41-year-old married women. She is from Lebanon and lives with her husband and three school-aged children. She has been working as a female hairdresser and beauty specialist for 17 years. In 2005, she decided to begin working from her own home. She helps her husband who works as an agent in a local company with the family income.

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase hair removal and tattoo machines so that she can enlarge her business and therefore increase her income.

loans.use: to purchase hair removal and tattoo machines

loans.name: Kiprono

texts.en:
Kiprono is a dairy farmer in the town of Litein in Kenya's Rift Valley. He has been practicing mixed farming for three years and sells his milk through Kenya Cooperative Creameries. He also earns income from small-scale farming of tea, which he sells locally.

He has requested for a loan of 80,000 KES through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to upgrade his dairy farming by constructing a zero-grazing unit, or animal pen,and buying a chaff cutter that will allow him to cut up animal feed. He hopes that his dairy farming will improve in future. His biggest challenge is lack of capital for expansion.

Kiprono is 25 years old and single.

loans.use: To buy a chaff cutter and construct a zero-grazing unit.

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.ar:
مصطفى في عمر 23 سنة يعمل في محل لبيع المناقيش اي فرن له في عمله 16 سنة يحب عمله ويريد دائما التطور والتجدد في العمل
متزوج وله 2 اولاد يحب اولاده ويسعى دائما الى تأمين الحياة الكريمة لهم وسبل العيش السليم في منزلهم لديه رغبة في تطوير
وتحسين المجتمع حوله يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى تصليح ودهن وتغيير مستلزمات المنزل يعمل بكد ونشاط يسعى وراء لقمة العيش
فقد ازداد عمله لانه يحب التطور والتحسين
texts.en: Mostafa, 23, is married with 2 children. He has been working at a bakery selling Manakeesh (a pizza-like popular Levantine food consisting of dough topped with thyme, cheese, or ground meat). Mostafa loves his children and seeks to secure a decent life for them. He also wishes to improve the status of his community. Mostafa wants to get a loan from Al Majmoua to repair, paint, and buy new items for his house. Mostafa works hard to earn his living. His business booms as he always works for its development.

loans.use: To buy painting materials and new items for his house

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 44-year-old married man. He is from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and three young children who are attending school. He has owned a fruit and vegetable shop since 2006. He sells his products to people from his community. He is the only income source of the family.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase his inventory so that he could improve his business, increasing his sales and therefore his income.

loans.use: to increase his inventory

loans.name: Margaret  Achieng

texts.en:
Margaret Achieng O. is 43 years old and married.  She and her husband Judas have grown children who are working.

Margaret has been selling charcoal in Kayole estate for 2 years now.  Her business has great potential because the area where she is located has many possible customers of both middle and low income.  She earns a profit of KES 10,000 per month. 

She is applying for her third loan of KES 70,000 from KADET LTD, after paying back the previous loans successfully. She plans to use the loan to open a stall and add to her stock of charcoal for sale. With her anticipated profit, she plans to  open another location for selling charcoal.

In the future she desires to grow her business and have a very large shop where she can supply charcoal to hotels. Margaret is active and a very hard-working lady. She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend.

loans.use: To open a stall and add to her stock of charcoal for sale

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David, 45, is married with six children, five of whom attend school. He has been practicing dairy farming for more than 10 years and employs one farmhand. He sells his milk to brokers in Litein town. He also earns income from his small-scale farming of tea which he sells locally.

He has requested a loan of 80,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to construct a zero-grazing unit, or animal pen. By constructing this unit, he will be able to improve his farming and this will increase his milk output. He says that his biggest challenge has been the poor breed of cows he owns.  He would like to improve the quality of his dairy cows to increase his milk production.

loans.use: To construct a zero-grazing unit, or animal pen

loans.name: Ali

texts.ar:
علي في عمر 21 سنة اعزب يعمل في محل للأنترنت وبيع اجهزة الكومبيوتر له في عمله حوال سنتين يحب عمله ويبرع فيه من خلال تطوير
نفسه وعمله يريد دائما التقدم والاستمرار في العمل حيث يحب له زبائن كثر من محيطه وجيرانه لكنه يواجه صعوبة في العمل 
حيث يلقى منافسة كبيرة من محيطه العملي لذلك فهو يريد من خلال طلب قرض له من المجموعة الى شراء وصيانة اجهزة الكومبيوتر
حتى يتمكن من استقبال عدد اكبر من الزبائن وبالتالي يزيد المدخول لديه حتى يتمكن من بناء مستقبل جيد له
texts.en: Ali, 21, is single. He has been working at a computer and internet shop for 2 years. Ali likes his work and always seeks to develop it. He has gotten many clients from his neighbors and those who know him. He faces a fierce competition at work so he wants to get a loan from Al Majmoua to buy more computers and to repair them as well.  The loan will help him gain more clients, increase his income, and build his future.

loans.use: To purchase more computers

loans.name: Ali

texts.ar:
علي متزوج وله 4 اولاد عمره 37 سنة يعمل في محل لبيع المواد الغذائية له في عمله 10 سنوات يحب عمله وعائلته كثيرا
يتمز علي بالنظافة في العمل والجد والنشاط يحب ان يزيد من مدخوله حتى تتمكن عائلته من التكيف مع المجتمع فهو يسعى جاهدا
الى اعطاء اولاده كل ما يستطيع من التعب والكد له تاريخ جيد حيث ساعده القرض السابق من تحسين وضع محله وتقدمه في العمل
يريد من خلال طلب قرض له من المجموعة الى زيادة تجارة جديدة وهي بيع قوارير الغاز له زبائن من جيرانه ومحيطه ويتميز عمله بأنه
المحل الوحيد القريب الى سكان هذا الحي
texts.en: Ali, 37, is married with four children. He has been working at a grocery store for 10 years. Ali loves his work and his family. He is known for caring about hygiene at work and for being active and a hard-worker. Ali wishes to increase his income to secure a good life for his family.  Ali works hard for the sake of his children. He has a good credit history with Al Majmoua. His previous loan helped him improve his business. He wants a loan from Al Majmoua to start a new business; He wants to start selling gas cylinders for cooking stoves. His clients are from his neighbors and people who know him. Ali owns the only grocery store in his neighborhood.

loans.use: To start a new business selling fuel

loans.name: Kiroket Ole

texts.en:
Kiroket Ole M. is 38 years old and married.  He supports six people.  Kiroket is a mixed farmer and he has been doing this for the last 15 years. His farm is in a productive area that supports mixed farming.

He learned about KADET through a marketing campaign done by the organization's staff near his home. This will be his third loan, and he is planning to use it to buy farm inputs. He hopes to use the profit resulting from this loan to build a new house and educate his children.

His hope and dream is to buy a plot and build rental houses. Kiroket is a young and energetic man who can do more if supported financially

loans.use: To buy farm inputs

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara has a mixed farm in Kitale town, western Kenya that produces milk and eggs which are sold locally. She mainly depends on the income from her farm to cater for the basic needs of her family.

She recently repaid a previous loan of 61,200Kes from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested another loan of 61,200Kes to purchase and maintain a dairy cow. She says that with the dairy cow she will acquire, her family will be guaranteed enough milk for domestic consumption and sale.

Sara is 44 years old and married with 4 children whose ages range between 7 and 20. Three of the children attend school.

loans.use: To purchase and maintain a dairy cow.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.ar:
حسن في عمر 52 سنة متزوج وله اربعة اولاد يعمل خياطة وتصليح الالبسة له في عمله حوالي 30 سنة يحب عمله ويريد دائما التجدد
والاستمرار في العمل ما يميز عمله انه له زبائن من محيطه وجيرانه يتميز بالدقة والتجديد في العمل يريد من خلال طلب قرض
له من المجموعة الى شراء عدة وبضائع جديدة للعمل يحلم بأن يصبح صاحب معمل لبيع الالبسة الجاهزة ولكنه يلقى صعوبة في تحقيق
حلمه فهو يريد البدء من الصفر حتى يستطيع تحقيق هذا الحلم
texts.en: Hasan, 52, is married with four children. He has been working as a tailor for 30 years. Hasan likes his work and always seeks to develop it. His clients are from his neighbors and people who know him. Hasan is known for his thorough and creative work. He wants to get a loan to buy news goods and tools. Hasan wishes to own an outlet for ready- made clothes one day but it is hard for him to achieve this dream. Hasan, however, is keen to achieve his dream so he is working from scratch to reach it.

loans.use: To buy new goods and tools for his sewing business

loans.name: Pascaliah Kwamboka

texts.en: Pascaliah Kwamboka O. is a 36 years old lady from Jomvu. She is married and together with her spouse they have  two children. She is a poultry farmer and has been in this business for the last one year. This marks her second loan from KADET LTD, and she plans to purchase two hundred chicks and repair her water selling Kiosk. The anticipated profits will be directed into the expansion of her poultry business. Her dream is to succeed in life.

loans.use: To purchase two hundred chicks and repair her water selling kiosk

loans.name: Sylvanos

texts.en:
Sylvanos has been practicing mixed farming for twenty years and employs two farmhands. His farm produces tomatoes, cabbages and maize which are all sold locally. He also earns income from his motorbike transport business.

He has requested a loan of 62,400Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and maintain a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable him pay school fees for his children. In five years' time, he hopes to have increased the number of his dairy cows and increase his milk production.

Sylvanos is 53 years old and married with 8 children whose ages range between 3 and 26. Four of the children attend school.

loans.use: To purchase and maintain a dairy cow.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane K. is a married lady. Her husband is a driver and they have three children aged between twenty nine years old and twenty one years old. Jane owns a tailor shop at Jogoo Market in Nairobi. She makes clothes for ladies and children. She has been in this business for nineteen years now. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more materials to increase her business and meet the demand of her customers. In future, she hopes to better her living standards. She describes herself as humble and resilient.

loans.use: To buy sewing materials

loans.name: Husein

texts.ar:
حسين يعمل في محل لبيع المواد الغذائية هو متزوج وله 3 اولاد له في عمله 20 سنة يتميز عمله بالدقة والصدق لديه خبرة كبيرة
